description: Master the core metrics and principles of web performance to build blazing fast user experiences

slides.title: Why Performance Matters?
slides.content:
# Web Performance Basics üöÄ

Performance is user experience. A 1-second delay in page load time can lead to a **7% reduction in conversions** and increased bounce rates.

slides.title: Core Web Vitals
slides.content:
# Google's Metrics üìä

1. **LCP (Largest Contentful Paint)**: Measures loading performance (aim for < 2.5s).
2. **FID (First Input Delay)**: Measures interactivity (aim for < 100ms).
3. **CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift)**: Measures visual stability (aim for < 0.1).

slides.title: The Network Waterfall
slides.content:
# Resource Loading üåä

Browsers load resources in a waterfall. One slow resource (like a giant 5MB image) can block everything else, including your JavaScript.

slides.title: Time to First Byte (TTFB)
slides.content:
# Server Power ‚ö°

TTFB is the time it takes for the browser to receive the first byte of data from the server. 

- **Slow TTFB**: Usually caused by slow DB queries, server logic, or bad routing.

slides.quizQuestion: Which metric measures how stable the page layout is as it loads?
slides.title: Metric Quiz
slides.content: Identifying Vitals.

slides.title: Perceived Performance
slides.content:
# Psychology of Speed üß†

Users don't just care about actual speed, but how fast it **feels**. 

- **Techniques**: Skeleton screens, optimistic UI, and progress bars.

slides.title: The Critical Rendering Path
slides.content:
# Browser Steps üõ†Ô∏è

1. **DOM**: HTML parsing.
2. **CSSOM**: CSS parsing.
3. **Render Tree**: Combining DOM & CSSOM.
4. **Layout**: Calculating positions.
5. **Paint**: Drawing pixels.

slides.title: Blocking Resources
slides.content:
# The Roadblocks üöß

By default, `<script>` and `<link rel="stylesheet">` block the rendering engine. 

- **Solution**: Use `defer` or `async` for scripts, and inline critical CSS.

slides.title: Analyzing with Lighthouse
slides.content:
# Continuous Audit üî¨

Use Chrome's built-in **Lighthouse** tool to get a performance score and a list of specific "Opportunities" to improve your site speed.

slides.quizQuestion: What does a 'Blocking Resource' do to the browser?
quizOptions: Prevents the browser from continuing to render the page until it is loaded
slides.title: Rendering Quiz
slides.content: Understanding bottlenecks.

slides.title: Network Latency
slides.content:
# Speed of Light üöÄ‚ú®

The physical distance between your user and your server matters. Requests across the Atlantic can take 100ms+ just in travel time.

slides.title: Payload Size
slides.content:
# Less is More üìâ

Smaller files load faster. Every extra KB of JavaScript takes time to download, parse, and execute, especially on mobile devices with weak CPUs.

slides.title: The Main Thread
slides.content:
# Single Lane Traffic üõ£Ô∏è

JavaScript runs on a single thread. If you run heavy calculations (like processing a large array), you freeze the UI, causing "jank" and high FID.

slides.title: Mobile First Performance
slides.content:
# 3G Reality üì±

Many users are on slow 4G or 3G networks. Always test your performance with **Network Throttling** enabled in DevTools to see the "real world". Or even better, a low-end Android device.

slides.quizQuestion: What is the recommended Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) for a good user experience?
slides.title: Target Quiz
slides.content: Goal setting.

slides.title: Optimization Hierarchy
slides.content:
# Priorities ü™ú

1. **Network**: CDNs, Caching.
2. **Payload**: Compression, Images.
3. **Render**: Critical CSS, JS execution.
4. **Code**: Algorithm efficiency.

slides.title: Web Workers
slides.content:
# Offloading Work üèóÔ∏è

Use **Web Workers** to run heavy scripts in the background, keeping the main thread free for smooth animations and user interactions.

slides.title: Browser Caching
slides.content:
# Memory üß†

The fastest request is the one that never happens. Leverage `Cache-Control` headers so the browser can reuse files from the local disk.

slides.title: Performance Budget
slides.content:
# Financial Discipline üí∞

Set limits like "My JS must be < 200KB" or "Homepage must load in < 3s". If a new feature breaks the budget, you must optimize something else first.

slides.quizQuestion: True or False: Lighthouse scores should only be measured on high-end desktop machines.
slides.title: Final Quiz
slides.content: Real-world testing.

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Summary üéâ

- ‚úÖ Focus on **Core Web Vitals** (LCP, FID, CLS).
- ‚úÖ Minimize **Blocking Resources**.
- ‚úÖ Reduce **Payload Size**.
- ‚úÖ Test on **slow networks and devices**.
- ‚úÖ Set a **Performance Budget**.

Building fast apps is about discipline and measureable goals! üöÄ
